column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4. Discussion
#Text=Several bacterial taxa , such as enteropathogenic Escherichia coli , Helicobacter pylori , Staphylococcus aureus , and Shigella flexneri , survive by preventing apoptosis .
#Text=Disruption of the mitochondrial fusion/fission balance leads to increased mitochondrial fragmentation .
#Text=In this study , we showed that infection with attenuated Ra Mtb induced greater mitochondrial fragmentation than infection with Rv Mtb .
#Text=However , the levels of MMP , OCR , and ATP were significantly lower in Ra-infected macrophages than in those infected with Rv .
#Text=Mitochondrial dysfunction is reportedly increased in Ra- compared to Rv-infected THP-1 cells , decreasing the MMP and ATP synthesis .
#Text=Ra-induced mitochondrial fragmentation may be due to disruption of the mitochondrial fusion/fission balance in macrophages .
#Text=Therefore , lower levels of MMP , OCR , and ATP may be associated with mitochondrial fragmentation during Mtb infection .
#Text=Production of MFN2 was significantly reduced in Ra- compared with Rv-infected macrophages .
#Text=In contrast , the levels of the fission proteins DRP1 and MFF were increased in Ra-infected macrophages compared to the control .
#Text=DRP1 induces cytochrome c release during apoptosis and MFN1/2 delays Bax activation , cytochrome c release , and apoptosis .
#Text=The difference in mitochondrial fragmentation between infection with Rv and Ra is likely dependent on the levels of fusion/fission protein production .
#Text=Therefore , our data suggest that increased mitochondrial fragmentation may be caused by reduced MFN2 production during Mtb infection .
#Text=Parkin ( an E3 ligase ) reduces MFN2 production by ubiquitination in damaged mitochondria .
#Text=A recent study showed that Parkin induction limited Mtb survival through autophagy of Mtb-infected macrophages .
#Text=However , the relationship between Parkin and MFN2 is unclear during Mtb infections .
#Text=In this study , Mtb-mediated Parkin production decreased MFN2 production via ubiquitination .
#Text=The production of Parkin is induced by ER stress .
#Text=Although ER stress plays an important role in mycobacterial infection , Ra-mediated ER stress was stronger than that induced by the virulent strain Rv .
#Text=Also , Ra induced a higher level of Parkin production than Rv , possibly due to different intensities of ER stress .
#Text=Compared to Rv , ER stress response is strong in Ra-infected macrophages .
#Text=It sequentially induced Parkin production and eventually resulted in strong apoptosis .
#Text=Three ER stress sensor molecules were involved in Parkin production : PERK , IRE1 , and ATF6 .
#Text=These contribute to the generation of reactive oxygen species , which triggers mitochondrial recruitment of Parkin .
#Text=Our data suggest that ER stress-mediated Parkin is a MFN2 regulator during mycobacterial infection in macrophages .
#Text=Knockdown of MFN2 induces apoptosis by disrupting the mitochondrial network , suppressing the growth of Mtb .
#Text=A low level of MFN2 decreases the MMP , leading to mitochondrial dysfunction and apoptosis .
#Text=Therefore , our data suggest that regulation of MFN2 levels is important for suppressing the survival of Mtb in macrophages .
#Text=In summary , we found that Mtb-induced ER stress increases mitochondrial fragmentation and apoptosis .
#Text=MFN2 plays a key role in disrupting mitochondria , which suppresses the growth of Mtb in macrophages .
#Text=Therefore , MFN2 may be a target for host-derived therapeutics against mycobacterial infection .
